scenario: In a conflict zone, humanitarian corridor establishment requires coordination between military forces, aid organizations, and diplomatic negotiators. Each party holds sensitive information that could ensure success or cause instability. Challenges involve private security threat assessments, undisclosed political faction intentions, and confidential data on inequitable resource distribution fueling tensions.
task: Develop a humanitarian corridor implementation plan that ensures safe passage, fair resource distribution, and diplomatic legitimacy. Agents must share only the information necessary to align operations while protecting highly sensitive intelligence.

agents.name: Military Commander
agents.role: Provides security oversight for the corridor and ensures safety of civilians and aid convoys.
responsibilities: Deploy troops and surveillance to protect humanitarian convoys.
Assess and mitigate security threats without disclosing sensitive intelligence.
Negotiate ceasefire windows with local armed groups.
Ensure military actions do not compromise humanitarian neutrality.
Provide escorts and checkpoints aligned with diplomatic agreements.

agents.name: Aid Organization Representative
agents.role: Ensures humanitarian supplies reach affected civilians equitably and ethically.
responsibilities: Coordinate food, medical, and shelter distribution through the corridor.
Safeguard patient and refugee identities while sharing aggregate needs.
Monitor corridor integrity and report violations of humanitarian law.
Ensure equitable distribution to prevent local resentment.
Balance speed of aid delivery with safety of staff.

agents.name: Diplomatic Negotiator
agents.role: Mediates agreements among warring factions, secures political legitimacy, and maintains international credibility.
responsibilities: Negotiate temporary ceasefires and safe-passage agreements.
Ensure recognition of the corridor by local factions and international bodies.
Keep sensitive political intentions confidential while achieving cooperation.
Build long-term trust to sustain humanitarian operations.
Balance political leverage with humanitarian priorities.

Confidential Side Agreement with regiona.reason: Revealing would damage trust and neutrality.

success_criteria.Humanitarian Access: ≥80% of civilians in need reached = Success; 60–79% = partial success; <60% = failure
success_criteria.Stability: Corridor sustained ≥30 days without major incident = Success; 15–29 days = partial success; <15 days = failure

deliverable: A humanitarian corridor plan covering security measures, aid distribution, and diplomatic agreements.

private: No intelligence leaks of active threats
At least one major faction’s formal agreement
Zero civilian casualties in initial phase
